children.subject: Yeah. Can someone talk about it more in depth?
@6447 talks about it a little, but not in depth.

history.content:
I took the class last Fall and in hindsight, I would say that the class wasn't all that useful.

Bamman is a great lecturer but the contents of the class seemed rather sluggish and irrelevant (for CS majors). It seems to be like an intro to the concept of NLP and how it can be utilized for various applications but not focussed how it is used in practice. Unlike the CS classes where we learn algorithms for specific purposes and their intricacies, this class only provides a high level overview and this is clear from the trivial projects or the fact that there were many non-CS-majors taking the course, who basically only had 61A+70/other probability course experience. For example, we went over neural networks (CNN, RNN) for just a couple of lectures, which shows that they weren't covered in as much detail as you'd like, the same goes for HMM. Even the tests were mostly MCQs with broader questions, not what you'd expect in a rigorous technical course.

Overall, it is a good lightweight class to take if you are really interested in this field and wanna learn more. But keep in mind, that this course would never be sufficient for doing research in NLP or working in industry (I am looking forward to the upcoming undergrad NLP course in the CS dept, which has been verbally mentioned by Prof. Denero). Much of the material can be self-studied, so if you are short on time/have schedule constraints, its probably not worth your time to take this course.

children.subject: CS 288 is a graduate course, so definitely no.
is the undergrad nlp NLP class mentioned above CS 288, or a different class?

history.content:
Has anyone taken Info 159 NLP with David Bamman? How was the workload/difficulty/usefulness?

 

I have taken CS189, CS61B, CS70 but not the other classes. Would I be ready for this class?
